display.text:
READ THE INSTRUCTIONS
CAREFULLY ON EACH PAGE.
Health care provider's ID number (optional):

Remember
  • Use the BACK and NEXT buttons within the software to navigate.

• Make sure the pulse oximeter is plugged into the tablet.

  • Check the remaining battery life and charge when necessary.
REMEMBER !
DO NOT DIAGNOSE OR TREAT THE CHILD BASED ON THE RESULTS OF THE mPNEUMONIA APPLICATION.
FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY.
ANY CHILD WITH DANGER SIGNS SHOULD BE EXCLUDED FROM THE STUDY:

• Not able to drink or breastfeed

  • Vomits everything

  • History of convulsion or convulsing now

  • Lethargic or unconscious

  • Other signs of severe/complicated illness

A child with any danger sign requires URGENT attention
and should be referred to another facility.
*Note: HIV assessment questions have purposely been omitted from this version of the application.
Patient Information
What is the child's gender?
Does the mother know the child's birthdate?

display.text:
Launch breath counter and press for EVERY breath observed.

Record count after 15 seconds.

SEVERE CONDITION PRESENT

Child should be referred URGENTLY to hospital.

display.text: FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY.

REMEMBER: Do NOT treat the child based on the results of the mPneumonia application.

Give fluid for dehydration (Plan C) before referral to hospital.
Can you give intravenous (IV) fluid immediately?
<li>If child can drink, teach the mother to give ORS by mouth while drip is set up.
<li>Give 75 ml/kg body weight Ringer's Lactate Solution (if not available, use normal saline).
Give {{evaluate calculates.planC}} ml Ringer's Lactate Solution (if not available, use normal saline).
First give 30 ml/kg for 1 hour*, then give 70 ml/kg in 5 hours  (Repeat if radial pulse is still very weak or not detectable)
First give {{evaluate calculates.firstHour}} ml for 1 hour* (Repeat if radial pulse is still very weak or not detectable)
Then give {{evaluate calculates.fiveHours}} ml in 5 hours
First give 30 ml/kg for 30 minutes*, then give 70 ml/kg in 2.5 hours  (Repeat if radial pulse is still very weak or not detectable)
First give {{evaluate calculates.firstHour}} ml for 30 minutes* (Repeat if radial pulse is still very weak or not detectable)
Then give {{evaluate calculates.fiveHours}} ml in 2.5 hours
<li>Reassess the child every 1-2 hours. If hydration status is not improving, give IV fluid more rapidly than stated.
<li>Also give ORS (5 ml/kg body weight/hour) as soon as the child can drink: usually after 1-2 hours (children) or 3-4 hours (infants)
• Also give {{evaluate calculates.ORS}} ml ORS per hour as soon as the child can drink (Usually after 1-2 hours (children) or 3-4 hours (infants).
<li>Do not stop the IV fluids until child has been observed to retain ORS for at least 1 hour and there is improvement in the clinical condition.
<strong>Rehydration of the child according to PLAN C may restore general danger signs so that referral is no longer needed.
display.hint:
If this is the case, continue ORS on Treatment Plan B. Continue to observe until child has no signs of dehydration.

Then move to Plan A.

menu.comments: SEVERE DEHYDRATION WITH ANOTHER SEVERE DISEASE
SEVERE PERSISTENT DIARRHOEA WITH ANOTHER SEVERE DISEASE

display.text: Prevent low blood sugar. Teach the mother to give frequent sips of oral rehydration solution (ORS) on the way to the hospital and advise the mother to continue breastfeeding.

Refer URGENTLY to hospital.

Is the child going to the hospital?
The caregiver acknowledges that the child requires URGENT attention and should be referred to a hospital for treatment of a severe condition.

Advise mother to bring the child to a hospital immediately 
for any of the following DANGER SIGNS:
  • Unable to drink or breastfeed
  • Vomiting everything
  • Convulsions
  • Lethargic or unconscious
(Optional) Feeding Recommendations

Advise the Mother to Increase Fluid and Continue Feeding During Illness.
  • If child is breastfed, breastfeed more frequently and for longer at each feed.
  • If taking milk substitutes, increase the amount of milk given
  • Increase other fluids: soup, rice water, coconut water, fruit juice, or clean water.
For a child with diarrhoea, giving extra fluid can be lifesaving.
Advise the mother to give 1- 2 extra feeds per day.

If child is not feeding well during illness
  • Feed more frequently and for longer if possible
  • Plan small, frequent meals
  • Give snacks between meals
  • Give high energy foods
  • Use soft, varied, appetizing, favourite foods to encourage the child to eat as much as possible
  • Clear a blocked nose if interferes with feeding
  • Expect that appetite will improve as child gets better

FOR PERSISTENT DIARRHOEA
  • If still breastefeeding, give more frequent, longer breastfeeds, day and night.
  • If taking other milk, replace with increasing breastfeeding OR replace half the milk with thick porridge

FOR MOUTH ULCERS
  • Give soft foods that will not burn the mouth, such as eggs, mashed potatoes, pumpkin, or avocado
  • Avoid spicy, salty, or acidic foods
  • Chop foods finely
  • Give cold drinks or ice, if available
FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY.
REMEMBER: Do NOT treat the child based on the results of the mPneumonia application.
Treatment Summary

Treat the Child in Clinic.
Tell the mother the reason for giving the drug to the child, and explain carefully how to give the drug at home.

display.text: Treat eye infection with Tetracycline or Chloramphenicol eye ointment.
<dd>Teach the mother how to clean both eyes 3 times daily

<dd><li>Wash hands<li>Ask the child to close the eye<li>Use clean cloth and water to gently wipe away pus<li>Ask the child to look up<li>Squirt a small amount of ointment on the inside of the lower lid<li>Wash hands again

Is Nystatin available?
<strong>Treat mouth ulcers with Gentian Violet (GV)
<dd>Teach the mother how to treat the mouth ulcers twice daily:
<dd><li>Wash hands<li>Wash the child's mouth with clean soft cloth wrapped around the finger and wet with salt water<li>Paint the mouth with half-strength gentian violet (0.25%)<li>Wash hands again.
The mother should continue to treat mouth ulcers with gentian violet for 5 days.
<strong>Treat for Thrush with Nystatin
<dd>Teach the mother how to treat for thrush FOUR TIMES daily for 7 days:

<dd><li>Wash hands<li>Wash the child's mouth with clean soft cloth wrapped around the finger and wet with salt water<li>Instill nystatin 1 ml four times a day<li>Avoid feeding for 20 minutes after medication<li>If breastfed, check mother's breasts for thrush and treat with nystatin<li>Advise mother to wash breasts after feeds. If bottlefed, advise to change to cup and spoon.

Dry the Ear by Wicking.
  • Roll clean absorbent cloth or soft strong tissue paper into a wick.
  • Place the wick in the child's ear.
  • Remove the wick when wet.
  • Replace the wick with a clean one and repeat these steps until the ear is dry.
  • Clean affected ear 3 times daily.
<dd><li>Instill Gentamycin or Ciprofloxacin eardrops after dry wicking 3 times daily for 14 days.

HIV Infection.
<b>Confirmed HIV Infection

• Initiate ART treatment and HIV care
  • Give cotrimoxazole prophylaxis*
  • Assess or refer for TB assessment and INH preventive therapy
  • Follow up regularly as per national guidelines
<b>HIV Exposed

• Give cotrimoxazole prophylaxis
  • Start or continue ARV prophylaxis as recommended
  • Do virological test to confirm HIV status***
  • Follow up regularly as per national guidelines
<b>HIV Infection Unlikely
<dd><li>Treat. Counsel, and follow-up existing infections

Advise mother to return immediately
if child has any of these signs:
Any sick child
  • Not able to drink or breastfeed
  • Becomes sicker
  • Develops a fever
    • If child has NO PNEUMONIA: COUGH OR COLD
  • Fast breathing
  • Difficult breathing
    • If child has DIARRHOEA, also return if:
  • Blood in stool
  • Drinking poorly

Advise mother to bring the child to a hospital immediately 
for any of the following DANGER SIGNS:
  • Unable to drink or breastfeed
  • Vomiting everything
  • Convulsions
  • Lethargic or unconscious
For child coughing for more than 2 weeks, please refer for detailed assessment.
For child with fever longer than 7 days, please refer for detailed assessment.

Feeding Recommendations
(relative to age)
6 months up to 12 months.
  • Breastfeed or give formula milk as often as the child wants
  • Give 3-4 times per day (4-5 times if not breastfed) an adequate serving of a variety of foods without pepper
  • Give fruit every day
  • Do not give water just before feeding
  • Wash both adult's and child's hands with soap and water before feeding

Feeding Recommendations
(relative to age)
12 months up to 2 years.
  • Breastfeed or give formula milk as often as the child wants
  • Feed 3 times per day an adequate serving of a variety of family foods
  • Give also, twie daily, snacks between main meals
  • Give fruit every day
  • Do not give water just before eating
  • Wash both adult's and child's hands with soap and water before eating
FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY.
REMEMBER: Do NOT give recommendations based on the results of the mPneumonia application.

Feeding Recommendations
(relative to age)
2 Years of Age and Older.
  • Feed 3 times per day an adequate serving of a variety of family foods
  • Give also, twie daily, snacks between main meals
  • Give fruit every day
  • Wash child's hands with soap and water before eating
FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY.
REMEMBER: Do NOT give recommendations based on the results of the mPneumonia application.
Feeding Recommendations

Advise the Mother to Increase Fluid and Continue Feeding During Illness.
  • If child is breastfed, breastfeed more frequently and for longer at each feed.
  • If taking milk substitutes, increase the amount of milk given
  • Increase other fluids: soup, rice water, coconut water, fruit juice, or clean water.
For a child with diarrhoea, giving extra fluid can be lifesaving.

Advise the mother to give 1- 2 extra feeds per day.
Continue for 2 weeks after the child gets better.

If child is not feeding well during illness.
  • Feed more frequently and for longer if possible
  • Plan small, frequent meals
  • Give snacks between meals
  • Give high energy foods
  • Use soft, varied, appetizing, favourite foods to encourage the child to eat as much as possible
  • Clear a blocked nose if interferes with feeding
  • Expect that appetite will improve as child gets better

FOR PERSISTENT DIARRHOEA
  • If still breastefeeding, give more frequent, longer breastfeeds, day and night.
  • If taking other milk, replace with increasing breastfeeding OR replace half the milk with thick porridge

FOR MOUTH ULCERS
  • Give soft foods that will not burn the mouth, such as eggs, mashed potatoes, pumpkin, or avocado
  • Avoid spicy, salty, or acidic foods
  • Chop foods finely
  • Give cold drinks or ice, if available

Examples of a Variety of Food, Snacks, and Fruits

A good daily diet should be adequate in quantity and include an energy rich food, meat, fish, eggs, or pulses; and fruits and vegetables.

• Porridge
    Thick koko made of maize (akasa), millet, sorghum, guinea corn or rice; ekwegbemi or other thick porridges like tombrown and weanimix with sugar and enriched with one or more of the following: palmoil, shea butter or other vegetable oil, groundnut paste, soya flour, bean flower, egg, milk, or fish powder. Porridge should be served with bread, bofrot, koose, maasa, kulikuli, or biscuit

• Give fruit every day
    Pawpaw, banana, pear, orange, pineapple, mango or watermelon.

• Family foods
    Waakye, rice, kenkey, banku, fufu, aboloo, gari, yam , cocoyam, plaintain, cassava, sweet potato, kokonte, akple, mpotompoto, gari-foto, aprapransa with palmoil or other vegetable oil and mashed fish, or tuozafi served with at least:
    - One ladle of stew: kontomire, beans, garden egg, okro, tomato, agushi, aleefu, bra, ayoyo, pumpkin, bokoboko all cooked with palm oil or other vegetable oil and mashed fish or meat.
    - One ladle of soup: groundnut, palmnut, neri, okro, vegetable soup with dawadawa or green leafy vegetables soup. All prepared with mashed fish, meat, egg or beans.

• Snacks between meals
    Bofrot, koose, maasa, bread, kulikuli, biscuit, doughnuts, egg, roasted or fried plantain or yam
FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY.
REMEMBER: Do NOT give advice based on the results of the mPneumonia application.
Counsel the Mother About Her Own Health.

If the mother is sick, provide care for her, or refer her for help.
    If she has a breast probem (engorgement, sore nipples, breast infection), provide care for her or refer her for help.
    Advise her to eat well to keep up her own strength and health.
    Check the mother's immunisation status and giver her tetanus toxoid (TT) if needed.
    Give pregnant woman IPT, if necessary.
    Make sure she has access to family planning and counseling on STI and AIDS prevention.

missingvaccinations.calculation: selected(data('birth'), 'yes') || selected(data('sixweeks'), 'yes')  || selected(data('tenweeks'), 'yes') || selected(data('fourteenweeks'), 'yes') || selected(data('sixmonths'), 'yes')  || selected(data('ninemonths'), 'yes')  || selected(data('oneyear'), 'yes')  || selected(data('eighteenmonths'), 'yes')

acuteEarInfection.calculation: selected(data('ear_discharge_reported'), 'yes') || selected(data('ear_pain'), 'yes') || selected(data('ear_discharge_observed'), 'yes') || data('ear_discharge_days') <= 14 && not(calculates.mastoiditis()) && calculates.reportEarProblem()

complication.calculation: calculates.anaemiaSevere() || calculates.mastoiditis() || selected(data('fever_yes_every_day'), 'yes') || calculates.severeComplicatedMeasles() || calculates.severePersistentDiarrhoea() || calculates.severeDehydration() || calculates.severePneumonia() || calculates.verySevereFebrileDisease()

Remember

REMEMBER !
DO NOT DIAGNOSE OR TREAT THE CHILD BASED ON THE RESULTS OF THE mPNEUMONIA APPLICATION.
FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY.
ANY CHILD WITH DANGER SIGNS SHOULD BE EXCLUDED FROM THE STUDY:

• Not able to drink or breastfeed

  • Vomits everything

  • History of convulsion or convulsing now

  • Lethargic or unconscious

  • Other signs of severe/complicated illness

A child with any danger sign requires URGENT attention
and should be referred to another facility.

prompts.comments: SEVERE PERSISTENT DIARRHOEA WITH ANOTHER SEVERE DISEASE

display.text: Prevent low blood sugar. Teach the mother to give frequent sips of oral rehydration solution (ORS) on the way to the hospital and advise the mother to continue breastfeeding.

Refer URGENTLY to hospital.

Is the child going to the hospital?
The caregiver acknowledges that the child requires URGENT attention and should be referred to a hospital for treatment of a severe condition.

Advise mother to bring the child to a hospital immediately 
for any of the following DANGER SIGNS:
  • Unable to drink or breastfeed
  • Vomiting everything
  • Convulsions
  • Lethargic or unconscious
(Optional) Feeding Recommendations

Advise the Mother to Increase Fluid and Continue Feeding During Illness.
  • If child is breastfed, breastfeed more frequently and for longer at each feed.
  • If taking milk substitutes, increase the amount of milk given
  • Increase other fluids: soup, rice water, coconut water, fruit juice, or clean water.
For a child with diarrhoea, giving extra fluid can be lifesaving.
Advise the mother to give 1- 2 extra feeds per day.

If child is not feeding well during illness
  • Feed more frequently and for longer if possible
  • Plan small, frequent meals
  • Give snacks between meals
  • Give high energy foods
  • Use soft, varied, appetizing, favourite foods to encourage the child to eat as much as possible
  • Clear a blocked nose if interferes with feeding
  • Expect that appetite will improve as child gets better

FOR PERSISTENT DIARRHOEA
  • If still breastefeeding, give more frequent, longer breastfeeds, day and night.
  • If taking other milk, replace with increasing breastfeeding OR replace half the milk with thick porridge

FOR MOUTH ULCERS
  • Give soft foods that will not burn the mouth, such as eggs, mashed potatoes, pumpkin, or avocado
  • Avoid spicy, salty, or acidic foods
  • Chop foods finely
  • Give cold drinks or ice, if available
FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY.
REMEMBER: Do NOT treat the child based on the results of the mPneumonia application.

Treat the Child in Clinic.
Tell the mother the reason for giving the drug to the child, and explain carefully how to give the drug at home.

<dd><li>Give Oral Antimalarial for treatment of malaria
Give Preventive Treatments in Clinic.
<dd><li>Give one dose of Vitamin A for measles
<dd><li>Give Iron for treatment of some anaemia
<dd><li>Give Mebendazole or Albendazole for children over 1 year with some anaemia
<dd><li>Give food, fluid, and Zinc supplements for treatment of diarrhoea

Give Extra Fluid for Diarrhoea/Continue Feeding.

<dd>Teach the mother how to clean both eyes 3 times daily

<dd><li>Wash hands<li>Ask the child to close the eye<li>Use clean cloth and water to gently wipe away pus<li>Ask the child to look up<li>Squirt a small amount of ointment on the inside of the lower lid<li>Wash hands again

Is Nystatin available?
<strong>Treat mouth ulcers with Gentian Violet (GV)
<dd>Teach the mother how to treat the mouth ulcers twice daily:
<dd><li>Wash hands<li>Wash the child's mouth with clean soft cloth wrapped around the finger and wet with salt water<li>Paint the mouth with half-strength gentian violet (0.25%)<li>Wash hands again.
The mother should continue to treat mouth ulcers with gentian violet for 5 days.
<strong>Treat for Thrush with Nystatin
<dd>Teach the mother how to treat for thrush FOUR TIMES daily for 7 days:

<dd><li>Wash hands<li>Wash the child's mouth with clean soft cloth wrapped around the finger and wet with salt water<li>Instill nystatin 1 ml four times a day<li>Avoid feeding for 20 minutes after medication<li>If breastfed, check mother's breasts for thrush and treat with nystatin<li>Advise mother to wash breasts after feeds. If bottlefed, advise to change to cup and spoon.

Dry the Ear by Wicking.
  • Roll clean absorbent cloth or soft strong tissue paper into a wick.
  • Place the wick in the child's ear.
  • Remove the wick when wet.
  • Replace the wick with a clean one and repeat these steps until the ear is dry.
  • Clean affected ear 3 times daily.
<dd><li>Instill Gentamycin or Ciprofloxacin eardrops after dry wicking 3 times daily for 14 days.

HIV Infection.
<b>Confirmed HIV Infection

• Initiate ART treatment and HIV care
  • Give cotrimoxazole prophylaxis*
  • Assess or refer for TB assessment and INH preventive therapy
  • Follow up regularly as per national guidelines
<b>HIV Exposed

• Give cotrimoxazole prophylaxis
  • Start or continue ARV prophylaxis as recommended
  • Do virological test to confirm HIV status***
  • Follow up regularly as per national guidelines
<b>HIV Infection Unlikely
<dd><li>Treat. Counsel, and follow-up existing infections
Check for Other Problems.
Does the child have any other health problems?
Assess the child for other health problems and treat according to Standard Treatment Guidelines, or refer.
FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY.

Advise When to Return to Health Worker.

Have the child return to the clinic for first follow-up in
2 days
5 days
7 days
14 days
30 days

Advise mother to return immediately
if child has any of these signs:
Any sick child
  • Not able to drink or breastfeed
  • Becomes sicker
  • Develops a fever
    • If child has NO PNEUMONIA: COUGH OR COLD
  • Fast breathing
  • Difficult breathing
    • If child has DIARRHOEA, also return if:
  • Blood in stool
  • Drinking poorly

Advise mother to bring the child to a hospital immediately 
for any of the following DANGER SIGNS:
  • Unable to drink or breastfeed
  • Vomiting everything
  • Convulsions
  • Lethargic or unconscious
For child coughing for more than 2 weeks, please refer for detailed assessment.
For child with fever longer than 7 days, please refer for detailed assessment.
Assess the Child's Feeding.
Assess the feeding of child under 2 years old or classified with malnutrition.
During this illness, has the child's feeding changed?

Assess the Child's Feeding.
What foods or fluids is the child taking?
How many times is the child fed in 24 hours?
How large are the servings?
Assess the Child's Feeding.
Who feeds the child and how?
Does the child receive his or her own serving?
FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY.
REMEMBER: Do NOT give recommendations based on the results of the mPneumonia application.

Feeding Recommendations
(relative to age)
Up to 6 months of age.

  • Breastfeed exclusively as often as the child wants, day and night
  • Feed at least 10 times in 24 hours
  • Do not give other foods or fluids
FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY.
REMEMBER: Do NOT give recommendations based on the results of the mPneumonia application.

Feeding Recommendations
(relative to age)
Up to 6 months of age.
  • Prepare correct strength and amount of formula just before use
  • Use within 2 hours and discard any left over (a fridge can store formula for 24 hours)
  • Cup feeding is safer than bottle feeding
  • Give these amounts of formula 6 to 8 times per day
FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY.
REMEMBER: Do NOT give recommendations based on the results of the mPneumonia application.

Feeding Recommendations
(relative to age)
6 months up to 12 months.
  • Breastfeed or give formula milk as often as the child wants
  • Give 3-4 times per day (4-5 times if not breastfed) an adequate serving of a variety of foods without pepper
  • Give fruit every day
  • Do not give water just before feeding
  • Wash both adult's and child's hands with soap and water before feeding
FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY.
REMEMBER: Do NOT give recommendations based on the results of the mPneumonia application.

Feeding Recommendations
(relative to age)
12 months up to 2 years.
  • Breastfeed or give formula milk as often as the child wants
  • Feed 3 times per day an adequate serving of a variety of family foods
  • Give also, twie daily, snacks between main meals
  • Give fruit every day
  • Do not give water just before eating
  • Wash both adult's and child's hands with soap and water before eating
FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY.
REMEMBER: Do NOT give recommendations based on the results of the mPneumonia application.

Feeding Recommendations
(relative to age)
2 Years of Age and Older.
  • Feed 3 times per day an adequate serving of a variety of family foods
  • Give also, twie daily, snacks between main meals
  • Give fruit every day
  • Wash child's hands with soap and water before eating
FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY.
REMEMBER: Do NOT give recommendations based on the results of the mPneumonia application.
Feeding Recommendations

Advise the Mother to Increase Fluid and Continue Feeding During Illness.
  • If child is breastfed, breastfeed more frequently and for longer at each feed.
  • If taking milk substitutes, increase the amount of milk given
  • Increase other fluids: soup, rice water, coconut water, fruit juice, or clean water.
For a child with diarrhoea, giving extra fluid can be lifesaving.

Advise the mother to give 1- 2 extra feeds per day.
Continue for 2 weeks after the child gets better.

If child is not feeding well during illness.
  • Feed more frequently and for longer if possible
  • Plan small, frequent meals
  • Give snacks between meals
  • Give high energy foods
  • Use soft, varied, appetizing, favourite foods to encourage the child to eat as much as possible
  • Clear a blocked nose if interferes with feeding
  • Expect that appetite will improve as child gets better

FOR PERSISTENT DIARRHOEA
  • If still breastefeeding, give more frequent, longer breastfeeds, day and night.
  • If taking other milk, replace with increasing breastfeeding OR replace half the milk with thick porridge

FOR MOUTH ULCERS
  • Give soft foods that will not burn the mouth, such as eggs, mashed potatoes, pumpkin, or avocado
  • Avoid spicy, salty, or acidic foods
  • Chop foods finely
  • Give cold drinks or ice, if available

Examples of a Variety of Food, Snacks, and Fruits

A good daily diet should be adequate in quantity and include an energy rich food, meat, fish, eggs, or pulses; and fruits and vegetables.

• Porridge
    Thick koko made of maize (akasa), millet, sorghum, guinea corn or rice; ekwegbemi or other thick porridges like tombrown and weanimix with sugar and enriched with one or more of the following: palmoil, shea butter or other vegetable oil, groundnut paste, soya flour, bean flower, egg, milk, or fish powder. Porridge should be served with bread, bofrot, koose, maasa, kulikuli, or biscuit

• Give fruit every day
    Pawpaw, banana, pear, orange, pineapple, mango or watermelon.

• Family foods
    Waakye, rice, kenkey, banku, fufu, aboloo, gari, yam , cocoyam, plaintain, cassava, sweet potato, kokonte, akple, mpotompoto, gari-foto, aprapransa with palmoil or other vegetable oil and mashed fish, or tuozafi served with at least:
    - One ladle of stew: kontomire, beans, garden egg, okro, tomato, agushi, aleefu, bra, ayoyo, pumpkin, bokoboko all cooked with palm oil or other vegetable oil and mashed fish or meat.
    - One ladle of soup: groundnut, palmnut, neri, okro, vegetable soup with dawadawa or green leafy vegetables soup. All prepared with mashed fish, meat, egg or beans.

• Snacks between meals
    Bofrot, koose, maasa, bread, kulikuli, biscuit, doughnuts, egg, roasted or fried plantain or yam
FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY.
REMEMBER: Do NOT give advice based on the results of the mPneumonia application.
Counsel the Mother About Her Own Health.

If the mother is sick, provide care for her, or refer her for help.
    If she has a breast probem (engorgement, sore nipples, breast infection), provide care for her or refer her for help.
    Advise her to eat well to keep up her own strength and health.
    Check the mother's immunisation status and giver her tetanus toxoid (TT) if needed.
    Give pregnant woman IPT, if necessary.
    Make sure she has access to family planning and counseling on STI and AIDS prevention.
